More Notes: The effect is a negative linear impact on regional growth rates. The value represents marginal losses per degree Celsius increase in variability.
Losses per extra degree of day-to-day temperature variability in regions with large seasonal temperature variations.
Losses per extra degree of day-to-day temperature variability in regions with small seasonal temperature differences.

Marginal change is estimated based on regional income levels, and country GDP per capita in 2017 US$. Countries with lower GDP per capita experience larger reductions in growth rates per degree of day-to-day temperature variability, because they tend to experience smaller seasonal temperature differences. This is a placeholder - a precise value is not provided on page 4.

Marginal losses from an increase in day-to-day temperature variability are generally larger for regions in low-income nations compared with those in higher-income nations, with the difference being more pronounced in higher-latitude countries
Marginal losses from an increase in day-to-day temperature variability are generally smaller and show a stronger response to the seasonal temperature difference
Marginal losses from an increase in day-to-day temperature variability are generally larger
The negative impacts of day-to-day variability persist for at least two years following the initial shock. There is evidence of a partial growth recovery in the third year
The effect on economic growth is a reduction of approximately one percentage point due to day-to-day temperature variability, based on their central econometric specification.

Marginal effects are negative, especially in regions with smaller seasonal temperature differences, and are relative to a baseline. The best estimate is 0.

Marginal effect of 1 degree increase in day-to-day temperature variability on regional growth rates for above-median income regions. The difference in response between high and low income is not significant. See Supplementary Table 9.

Marginal effect of 1 degree increase in day-to-day temperature variability on regional growth rates for below-median income regions. The difference in response between high and low income is not significant. See Supplementary Table 9.
